Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Action, Learning, and Social Cognition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to understand other people's goals and intentions is critical for social competence. A key component of this is interpreting the reasons for others' actions. Infants appear to be able to determine others' goals based on observing others' actions early in life, and this sensitivity to others' goals is associated with developments in infants' own ability to perform goal-based actions. The purpose of this project is to investigate the neural and cognitive systems that support infants' emerging sensitivity to goal-based actions in themselves and others. This work will shed new light on how neurocognitive development supports early social cognition.

The proposed studies will record electroencephalogram (EEG), a technique for recording the brain's electrical activity, while 8- to 10-month-old infants perform actions on objects, when they perform joint actions with others, and when they observe others' actions. A first goal of the research is to characterize the neural processes that are involved when infants learn to engage in new actions and social collaborations. A second goal is to test the prediction that these neural processes also support infants' understanding of others' goal-directed actions. To address these issues, the research will evaluate networks of neural activity as infants act and observe others' actions, and will assess whether these patterns of neural activity predict when infants are able to respond appropriately to others' goal-directed actions. Beyond addressing the focal research questions, the proposed studies will generate new approaches to analyzing infant neural and cognitive development, and the findings of these studies with typically-developing infants may help to shed light on developmental disorders that affect social cognition and social behavior. The project will provide unique multidisciplinary training opportunities for students and postdoctoral researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Prior research had shown that infants' understanding of other people's actions is related to their own experiences engaging in actions. In this project we aimed to investigate the neural and cognitive processes that account for this relationship. We began by investigating infants' action understanding using a behavioral paradigm. We assessed infants' tendency to imitate others' actions as an indicator of their understanding of those actions. We found that training infants to produce a novel tool use action changed their understanding of that action in others. Next, we investigated the neural processes that may be related to infants' action production and  their understanding of others' actions. We recorded electroencephalogram (EEG) while 9- and 12-month-old infants observed another person producing a simple familiar action (reaching for a toy) and a novel action (using a tool to retrieve a toy). Consistent with prior research, we found a specific neural response, mu rhythm ERD, when infants viewed others' actions. However, we were surprised to find that this response was present regardless of whether the action was familiar or novel.  Some researchers have interpreted the mu ERD response as a signal of motor familiarity, but our findings suggest this may not be a sound assumption. Instead, we found that patterns of interconnectivity differentiated between infants' responses to novel and familiar actions. When viewing the familiar actions, infants showed a pattern of heightened connection between activity at central (motor) and occipital (visual) sites. This pattern was not found when infants viewed the novel action. Further, we found that neural activity during the observation of the familiar reaching action correlated with infants' own skill in reaching, but no relation was observed for the novel action. Taken together, our findings provide new insights into the neural processes that underlie infants? perception of others' actions.

 In conducting this work, we built on a productive research collaboration between our laboratory and Nathan Fox's laboratory at the University of Maryland. Postdocs and students visited across labs to be trained in the relevant methods, and Fox's team provided critical expertise and advice for the analysis of the EEG data. This environment provided excellent opportunities for student and postdoctoral training in EEG and behavioral methods.

The broader impacts of this project included the development of EEG analysis pipelines and approaches for use with infant data, and training opportunities for graduate students, college students and postdoctoral researchers that drew on the collaboration across the Woodward and Fox laboratories.
